By definition, phenotypic plasticity is the process by which a single genotype gives rise to different phenotypes in different circumstances.

106 The plasticity is known as an epigenetic effect. Phenotypic plasticity in animals exposed to a change in environment may involve acclimation, acclimatization, and learning
104 and can take place through phenology, developmental plasticity, physiological adjustments and behavioral flexibility.
107 Unlike genetic adaptation, phenotypic plasticity allows the animal itself, rather than its future lineage (except in the case of maternal effects; see below), to respond to environmental change.
108 The mechanism of plasticity can involve changes to the way that DNA is packaged in the nucleus and alters the probability of a particular gene being expressed.
